message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the mass and the fact that it moves when the patient swallows suggest that it is a cyst formation in a persistent thyroglossal duct. The other options are less likely to present in this manner.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location and description of the mass suggest a thyroglossal duct cyst, which is a remnant of embryonic development. None of the other options are consistent with the location and description of the mass.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the mass and the fact that it moves when the patient swallows suggest that it is a cyst formed in a persistent thyroglossal duct. Persistent thyroid tissue at the tongue base would present differently and a deletion of the 22q11 gene is associated with DiGeorge syndrome, which presents with several other symptoms. Lymph node enlargement would be tender and associated with other symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the mass, above the hyoid bone but below the level of the mandible, and the fact that it moves when the patient swallows, suggest a cyst formed in a persistent thyroglossal duct. Persistent thyroid tissue at the tongue base or deletion of the 22q11 gene would not present as a midline neck mass, and lymph node enlargement would typically be accompanied by erythema and systemic symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location and mobility of the mass suggest that it is a cyst formation in a persistent thyroglossal duct. Persistent thyroid tissue at the tongue base would present as a lingual thyroid, while deletion of the 22q11 gene is associated with DiGeorge syndrome. Lymph node enlargement would present as a non-midline mass and would likely be associated with other symptoms such as fever or pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location and description of the lump suggest that it is a cyst that formed from a persistent thyroglossal duct. Persistent thyroid tissue at the tongue base would not present as a midline neck mass. Deletion of the 22q11 gene would present with other symptoms and abnormalities. Lymph node enlargement would present with other clinical findings such as tenderness, warmth, or redness.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location and mobility of the mass suggest that it is likely a cyst formation in a persistent thyroglossal duct. Persistent thyroid tissue at the tongue base and deletion of the 22q11 gene would present in different ways. Lymph node enlargement would likely have other associated symptoms such as fever or pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s presentation is consistent with a cyst formation in a persistent thyroglossal duct, which is a common cause of midline neck masses in children. The other options are less likely based on the patient’s clinical presentation and normal CBC and thyroid function tests.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the mass, midline and above the hyoid bone but below the level of the mandible, is consistent with a cyst formation in a persistent thyroglossal duct. All other options do not fit with the patient’s symptoms and physical exam findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the mass and the fact that it moves with swallowing suggests that it is a thyroglossal duct cyst. Persistent thyroid tissue at the tongue base would be lower and not move with swallowing, while deletion of the 22q11 gene is associated with DiGeorge syndrome and presents with a variety of symptoms. Lymph node enlargement would be associated with erythema and likely fever.
